statement.text: Loeys-Dietz syndrome (LDS) is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in TGF-β pathway genes (TGFBR1, TGFBR2, SMAD3, TGFB2, TGFB3), characterized by arterial tortuosity, widespread aneurysms, hypertelorism, and bifid uvula. LDS carries a more aggressive vascular phenotype than Marfan syndrome, with dissection occurring at smaller aortic diameters.
statement.formal: LDS: AD, TGF-β pathway mutations (5 types); Features: arterial tortuosity, aneurysms beyond aortic root, hypertelorism, bifid uvula; More aggressive than Marfan - dissection at smaller sizes

explanation.intuition: If Marfan syndrome affects the scaffolding of blood vessels, Loeys-Dietz is like having that scaffolding improperly assembled from the start. The TGF-β signaling pathway is crucial for how blood vessels develop and maintain their structure. When this pathway malfunctions, arteries throughout the body become abnormally twisted and prone to aneurysms - not just the aortic root.
explanation.key_insight: LDS patients dissect at smaller aortic diameters than Marfan patients. Intervention thresholds are therefore lower (typically 4.0-4.5 cm for the aortic root vs 5.0 cm in Marfan). Additionally, aneurysms occur throughout the arterial tree, requiring head-to-pelvis surveillance imaging.
explanation.technical_details: Five LDS types based on causative gene: LDS1 (TGFBR1), LDS2 (TGFBR2), LDS3 (SMAD3), LDS4 (TGFB2), LDS5 (TGFB3). LDS1/2 are most common and most severe. Characteristic triad: arterial aneurysm/tortuosity + hypertelorism (widely-spaced eyes) + bifid/broad uvula. Unlike Marfan, ectopia lentis is NOT seen in LDS.

vascular: Aneurysms beyond aortic root (carotid, vertebral, intracranial, abdominal)

vascular_manifestations.aortic_root: Most common, similar to Marfan but dissects at smaller size
vascular_manifestations.cervical_arteries: Carotid and vertebral tortuosity and aneurysm
vascular_manifestations.pregnancy_risk: Very high - uterine rupture, aortic dissection

differentiation_from_marfan: Hypertelorism and bifid uvula in LDS
Widespread aneurysms beyond aortic root in LDS

definition.@value: Autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder due to TGF-β pathway mutations, with arterial tortuosity, aneurysms, and craniofacial features

clinical_pearls: LDS dissects at smaller diameters than Marfan - intervene earlier (4.0-4.5 cm)
No ectopia lentis - this differentiates from Marfan
Requires head-to-pelvis surveillance - aneurysms occur throughout arterial tree
Pregnancy is extremely high-risk - preconception counseling essential
